Does not respond to the Small Boy's question about having a nightmare, showing emotional reserve or detachment.
Wakes up quickly and looks around to get his bearings on a crowded airplane.
Does not respond when a small boy asks if he had a nightmare, showing controlled silence and composure despite possible distress.
Warns the Small Boy about the dangers of the dark and the truth about fear, contradicting comforting lies to keep him safe.

Acknowledges the protective value of fear and conveys hard-earned knowledge about real dangers, showing insight and experience.
